metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Responsive Web Design - Media Queries
What is a Media Query?
Media query is a CSS technique introduced in CSS3.
content.html: Media query is a CSS technique introduced in CSS3.

content.text: It uses the @media rule to include a block of CSS properties only if a certain condition is true.
content.html: It uses the @media rule to include a block of CSS properties only if a certain condition is true.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {  body {
   
background-color: lightblue;  }}

content.code:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {  body {

background-color: lightblue;  }}

syntax_highlighting.text:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {  body {
   
background-color: lightblue;  }}

content.code_html:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {
  body {
    background-color: lightblue;
  }
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {  body {
   
background-color: lightblue;  }}

content.text: Add a Breakpoint
Earlier in this tutorial we made a web page with rows and columns, and it was responsive, but it did not look good on a small screen.
content.html: Earlier in this tutorial we made a web page with rows and columns, and it was responsive, but it did not look good on a small screen.

content.text: Media queries can help with that. We can add a breakpoint where certain parts of the design will behave differently on each side of the breakpoint.
content.html: Media queries can help with that. We can add a breakpoint where certain parts of the design will behave differently on each side of the breakpoint.

content.code_html:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {
  .item1 {grid-area: 1 / span 6;}
  .item2 {grid-area: 2 / span 6;}
  .item3 {grid-area: 3 / span 6;}
  .item4 {grid-area: 4 / span 6;}
  .item5 {grid-area: 5 / span 6;}
}

content.text: Another Breakpoint
You can add as many breakpoints as you like.
content.html: You can add as many breakpoints as you like.

content.text: We will also insert a breakpoint between tablets and mobile phones.
content.html: We will also insert a breakpoint between tablets and mobile phones.

content.code_html:
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {
  .item1 {grid-area: 1 / span 6;}
  .item2 {grid-area: 2 / span 6;}
  .item3 {grid-area: 3 / span 6;}
  .item4 {grid-area: 4 / span 6;}
  .item5 {grid-area: 5 / span 6;}
}

@media only screen and (min-width: 600px) {
  .item1 {grid-area: 1 / span 6;}
  .item2 {grid-area: 2 / span 1;}
  .item3 {grid-area: 2 / span 4;}
  .item4 {grid-area: 3 / span 6;}
  .item5 {grid-area: 4 / span 6;}
}

@media only screen and (min-width: 768px) {
  .item1 {grid-area: 1 / span 6;}
  .item2 {grid-area: 2 / span 1;}
  .item3 {grid-area: 2 / span 4;}
  .item4 {grid-area: 2 / span 1;}
  .item5 {grid-area: 3 / span 6;}
}

content.text: Typical Device Breakpoints
There are tons of screens and devices with different heights and widths, so it is hard to create an exact breakpoint for each device. To keep things simple you could target five groups:
content.html: There are tons of screens and devices with different heights and widths, so it is hard to create an exact breakpoint for each device. To keep things simple you could target five groups:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
/* Small devices (portrait tablets and large phones, 600px and up) 
  */

syntax_highlighting.text:
/* Small devices (portrait tablets and large phones, 600px and up) 
  */

content.code_html:
/* Extra small devices (phones, 600px and down) */
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {...}

/* Small devices (portrait tablets and large phones, 600px and up) */
@media only screen and (min-width: 600px) {...}

/* Medium devices (landscape tablets, 768px and up) */
@media only screen and (min-width: 768px) {...}

/* Large devices (laptops/desktops, 992px and up) */
@media only screen and (min-width: 992px) {...}

/* Extra large devices (large laptops and desktops, 1200px and up) */
@media only screen and (min-width: 1200px) {...}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
/* Small devices (portrait tablets and large phones, 600px and up) 
  */

content.text: Orientation: Portrait / Landscape
Media queries can also be used to change layout of a page depending on the orientation of the browser.
content.html: Media queries can also be used to change layout of a page depending on the orientation of the browser.

content.text: You can have a set of CSS properties that will only apply when the browser window is wider than its height, a so called "Landscape" orientation:
content.html: You can have a set of CSS properties that will only apply when the browser window is wider than its height, a so called "Landscape" orientation:

content.code_html:
@media only screen and (orientation: landscape) {
  body {
    background-color: lightblue;
  }
}

content.text: Hide Elements With Media Queries
Another common use of media queries, is to hide elements on different screen sizes:
content.html: Another common use of media queries, is to hide elements on different screen sizes:

syntaxHighlighting.text: /* If the screen size is 600px wide or less, hide the element */

syntax_highlighting.text: /* If the screen size is 600px wide or less, hide the element */

content.code_html:
/* If the screen size is 600px wide or less, hide the element */
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {
  div.example {
    display: none;
  }
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: /* If the screen size is 600px wide or less, hide the element */

content.text: Change Font Size With Media Queries
You can also use media queries to change the font size of an element on different screen sizes:
content.html: You can also use media queries to change the font size of an element on different screen sizes:

content.text: Variable Font Size.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
/* If the screen size is 601px or 
  more, set the font-size of <div> to 80px */

syntax_highlighting.text:
/* If the screen size is 601px or 
  more, set the font-size of <div> to 80px */

content.code_html:
/* If the screen size is 601px or more, set the font-size of <div> to 80px */
@media only screen and (min-width: 601px) {
  div.example {
    font-size: 80px;
  }
}

/* If the screen size is 600px or less, set the font-size of <div> to 30px */
@media only screen and (max-width: 600px) {
  div.example {
    font-size: 30px;
  }
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
/* If the screen size is 601px or 
  more, set the font-size of <div> to 80px */

content.text: CSS @media Reference
For a full overview of all the media types and features/expressions, please look at the @media rule in our CSS reference .
content.html: For a full overview of all the media types and features/expressions, please look at the @media rule in our CSS reference.
